questions.question_text: Which of the following is a client-server tool utilized to evade firewall inspection?

discussion.content:
A. DataThief

Purpose: DataThief is a tool for digitizing data from images of graphs, not for SQL injections or database exploitation.
Fit: Not suitable for SQL injection tasks.
D. SQLInjector

Purpose: SQLInjector (or tools with similar names) is specifically built to automate SQL injection attacks, making it the most relevant choice for exploiting a database via SQL injection.
Fit: Fits the use case perfectly. 
D should be the answer.What do you think?

Selected Answer: D
Does DataThief Automate SQL injection? What if SQL Injector since it also a tool but AUTOMATE SQL injections attacks and exploit database connections by manipulating the web application's interaction with the database. What do you think? i think SQL is more suitable for the task described.

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer

DataThief is a tool used to demonstrate to web administrators and developers how to steal data from a web application that is vulnerable to SQL Injection. Data Thief is designed to retrieve the data from a Microsoft SQL Server back-end behind a web application with a SQL Injection vulnerability. 

https://diarium.usal.es/pmgallardo/2020/11/02/list-of-sql-injection-tools/
This answer should be D as datathief is a reverse engineering tool

comments.content: I think there are two tools with the same name. 'DataThief' is the reverse engineering tool, but 'Data Thief' (with a space) appears to be an automated SQL injection tool. So it's more a typo than a wrong answer

questions.question_text: Which tool is used to automate SQL injections and exploit a database by forcing a given web application to connect to another database controlled by a hacker?

discussion.content: A network tap is a system that monitors events on a local network.[citation needed] A tap is typically a dedicated hardware device, which provides a way to access the data flowing across a computer network. In many cases, it is desirable for a third party to monitor the traffic between two points in the network. If the network between points A and B consists of a physical cable, a network tap may be the best way to accomplish this monitoring.

questions.question_text: When using Wireshark to acquire packet capture on a network, which device would enable the capture of all traffic on the wire?
Smart cards use which protocol to transfer the certificate in a secure manner?

discussion.content: The Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) is a protocol for wireless networks that expands the authentication methods used by the Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP), a protocol often used when connecting a computer to the internet. EAP is used on encrypted networks to provide a secure way to send identifying information to provide network authentication. It supports various authentication methods, including as token cards, smart cards, certificates, one-time passwords and public key encryption.

choices.D: 10.0.0.252 is performing an IP scan against 10.0.0.2, 10.0.0.252 is performing a port scan against 10.0.0.2.
choices.B: 10.0.0.253 is performing an IP scan against 10.0.0.2, 10.0.0.252 is performing a port scan against 10.0.0.2.
choices.C: 10.0.0.2 is performing an IP scan against 10.0.0.0/24, 10.0.0.252 is performing a port scan against 10.0.0.2.
choices.A: 10.0.0.253 is performing an IP scan against 10.0.0.0/24, 10.0.0.252 is performing a port scan against 10.0.0.2.

questions.question_text:
From the two screenshots below, which of the following is occurring?
//IMG//

discussion.content:
None of this is correct, must be some kind of terminology issue here, let's dig in. 
.253 is nmap -sP .0/24
.252 is nmap -sO .2

Command: -sO is found here https://nmap.org/book/scan-methods-ip-protocol-scan.html
Command: -sP is found here https://nmap.org/book/man-host-discovery.html

So -sP is NOT a port scan and it's also not an IP protocol scan. But what is this "IP scan" mentioned in every answer? I would have to assume they mean "IP protocol scan" which is -sO. But none of the answers match correctly even with the terminology changed to the IP protocol scan. So then does "IP scan" mean any scan other than a port scan? If that's the case then none of the answers match either since 252 is NOT performing a port scan. SIGH, IDK...
Answer A states the same information as Answer D does, but then also includes the correct information for the first scan, this is why A is correct.

comments.content: While A is correct, your explanation is not. D does not have the /24
you missed out the /24 information that makes A the correct answer.

discussion.content: Should be D, -sO is IP protocol scan
